awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NSF/DOE Partnership on Advanced Combustion Engines: Advancing Low Temperature Combustion and Lean Burning Engines for Light- and Heavy-Duty Vehicles with Mi
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
#1258653 / Dibble, Robert W.
#1258626 / Cheng, Wai K.


The goal of this research project is to help achieve the 54 mile-per-gallon vehicle mileage target (year 2025) by providing experimental data, simulation tools and understanding of fundamental phenomena to develop the next generation of high efficiency engines for vehicles.  Our objective is the extension of clean and efficient low temperature combustion (LTC) technology to operate over the full load and speed range required of an engine.  Two main two technology paths are explored: 1) partial fuel stratification (PFS) in LTC compression ignition engines, and 2) microwave assisted spark plugs (µWASP) combined with PFS in spark-ignited engines.  This program has significant collaboration with the Combustion Research Facility at Sandia National Laboratories,  the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Ricardo Inc. ( for automotive testing ), and the Clean Combustion Research Center of KAUST.

On a fundamental level, this program will provide detailed understanding of the chemical kinetics that cause pressure-sensitive intermediate temperature heat release and equivalence ratio sensitivity in gasoline, phenomena that enable high load boosted LTC with PFS. For the ìWASP technology, this program will provide understanding of the interactions between the spark discharge, the microwave field and the stratified mixture in the flame kernel formation process.  Additionally, the fundamental physics behind flame propagation through a stratified charge will be studied to obtain a comprehensive description of the PFS ignition process.  These scientific insights will be applied, through fundamentally based phenomenological models, to engines for improving engine efficiency and lowering emissions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Continuous improvement in the efficiency of current practical combustion devices and on the magnitude of emission reduction remains a necessary step in order to solve immediate climate and air-pollution issues and to ensure a smooth transition to the renewable energy era. The outcomes of this project have contributed to the increasing understanding of the combustion processes in advanced internal combustion engines, which support almost the entire energy demand for transportation and other industrial applications.

This project first investigated the use of partial fuel stratification (PFS) enabling Low Temperature Combustion (LTC) engines to operate over the full load and speed range. On a fundamental level, this research activity provided a detailed understanding of the chemical kinetics that causes pressure-sensitive heat release and equivalence ratio sensitivity in typical liquid fuels including gasoline and ethanol. The outcomes have improved the capability of liquid fuel usage towards optimal efficiency and emission characteristics. Second, a variety of advanced ignition techniques, including microwave-assisted spark plug, nanosecond pulse nanosecond pulsed discharge, and corona discharge ignition systems were investigated. The corresponding research activity provided an understanding of the interactions between the spark discharge, the electric field and the stratified mixture in the flame kernel formation process, and identified the critical importance of electrode design and the beneficial coupling between the detailed non-thermal plasma chemistry and the hydrodynamics associated with these real ignition devices. The results contributed to the development of robust ignition systems in modern boosted, downsized, heavy-EGR engines. Third, the fundamental physics underlying flame propagation through a stratified charge were studied and a comprehensive description of the PFS combustion process was obtained. The effect of fuel stratification on flame speeds of various stratified fuel/air mixtures were investigated by a detailed numerical study to gain insights. These scientific insights have been used for development of phenomenological models for predictions of flame speeds in PFS.

The new knowledge base design tools from the above three research components will enable improvement of future engines with significant engine efficiency gains (25-40% from current practice) while maintaining low emissions across a wide range of load and speed. In addition, the project supported the education of several graduate and undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral scholars in energy and combustion sciences. The above projects provided opportunities for these young researchers to develop skills in critical and logical thinking as well as research methodologies and methods. This project has trained the next-generation professionals for leadership positions in science and engineering in industry, academia and national laboratories.


Last Modified: 09/30/2017
Modified by: Jyh-Yuan Chen
